reviewText:
When I first saw this film I was agog at the interesting and thoughtful treatment of the characters and the situation they found themselve in.  I had not read any reviews and so was completely unprepared and astonished.  I cannot write about it without risking spoiling the clever and unexected conclusion.  And reading reviews and/or descriptions of the film may rob you of one of the greatest surprises in today's cenima.

I think that once you see it you will want tell others about it so that they can share in your experience.  But you will be limited in what ou can say without spoiling it.

The casting is spot on.  Martin Landau gives one of his best performances.  The plot development is subtle and takes several unexpected twist and turns.  I rated this film as one of the best I had seen.

If you are in a situation involving older people, this is a must see.  But, it is not a film about being old but about being human and how unexpected some of the paths leading into the future can turn out to be.

If you want a good and thought provoking experience, Lovely Still is for you.

"When I saw you everything fit. It was like breathing."

I hope someone someday says something like that to me. If you have heard those sentiments, bless you.  Like the one who loves you, your love brings light into the world.

This is a sweet wonderful film.  It begins gently. Give it the time. If you do, it will weave it's magic, capturing and cradling your heart as the story unfolds before you.

I especially liked the scene in which Mary (Ellen Burstyn) asks Martin (Martin Landau) to spent the next day, Christmas Day, with her. Martin, looking sad and pensive as though he's looking into the past, replies that he has never spent Christmas Day with anyone.  Mary pauses.  Looks up at him, and seeing his mood says cheerily, "So is that a "yes"?" With those fives words she acknowledges his mood, and nudges him back into the present moment. It's a moment that offers a future together as a sweet promise.

And to top it all off, the music is wonderful.

The screen play writing and acting of the principals in this film is outstanding, especially that of Martin Landau who delivers an Oscar caliber performance. I first saw this movie at the Milwaukee Film Festival where Martin Landau and the writer/director engaged the audience in a delightful question and answer session. Since then I have eagerly awaited its general release. The story is touching and poignant, funny, uplifting and sad at the same time. One of my favorite movies.

This is an extraordinary movie. I can't believe the director is so young - his wisdom is way beyond his years. Landau and Burstyn are luminous and un-Botoxed in this haunting drama about what true love really is. Be sure to watch very carefully as the details give insight into what is quickly revealed at the end - that is how everybody is really related. I have been thinking about it daily since I saw it. You will never forget it!

What a lovely surprise - loved it!  It stayed with me for days after.  I kept remembering snippets of it.  It's not what I thought it was. The story unfolds slowly and subtly clues are dropped that something is more then what it seems.  Robert is an elderly guy living alone and he works at a supermarket.  Mary is his new elderly next door neighbor.  Mary encourages Robert and they start a relationship.

It's filmed in Omaha, Nebraska during the Christmas season.  There's lots of snow, which is beautiful and creates one of the most memorable scenes.  Robert notices the falling snow and says something like, was it always this beautiful, did we miss it?  Mary encourage Robert to live in the present.  The acting, the story and the visuals are wonderful.  The morning rituals of Roberts waking up and grooming are funny and full of emotion, what a great actor Martin Landau is!  There are many funny and poignant scenes. For example, Robert soliciting advice from others on that ever so important first date.  Ellen Burstyn, as Mary, is fabulous too in this role.  The chemistry between the two seems real.  The two main supporting roles of Mary's daughter, Elizabeth Banks,  and Robert's manager, Adam Scott, are well acted, interesting, and add depth to the story.  A timeless favorite! I highly recommend it. It's ok if you cry!

A sweet and loving courtship and romantic adventure unfolds between a smitten very senior pair. One evening Robert ( Martin Landau), returning from his job at the grocery, is stunned to find Mary (Ellen Burstyn) in his home. She quickly invents a reason and he's satisfied. Their romance is set in a winter landscape at Christmas time. The seasonal music, lights, artistic stage sets and the movement of the characters from icy snowy outdoors to cozy toasty interiors generate a just-right nostalgic holiday atmosphere. Sensitivity and caring between and among the characters, including Adam Scott and Elizabeth Banks' characters is smartly developed. The story treats love in the twilight years with grace and appreciation, and displays bountiful artistic skill. To tell more would spoil. The only element I didn't like was the use of sort of kaleidoscopic, swirling, somewhat chaotic imagery in the interludes suggesting Robert's confusion upon arising. It felt a bit amateurish. But the film is an excellent one, with a lovely storyline ( Nik Fackler and Tim Kasher), skilled directing (Fackler) and exceptional performances by a talented cast. Recommend.

I hate spoilers, but I don't know how else to explain why this movie made me so angry. I wish movie makers would stop romanticizing the disease we shall call "A." The premise of this movie is utterly inane. A woman leaves a man with A alone so she can live out some twisted fantasy of reviving him with romance. A person with A so advanced he doesn't recognize his family members cannot live alone, cannot get himself dressed and make breakfast, cannot brew coffee, remember to take pills, find his way to work and back, etc. He certainly cannot recognize a "new" woman in his life from one day to the next, remember her name and be cognizant enough of time and circumstance to say, "I've only known you for a week, but tomorrow I'm going to ask you to marry me." Suddenly, short-term memory is no problem?!? And what's with that oddball subplot about prescription pills? There is no effective pill for A, so why is she all agita about him missing a few pills? What pills are these?!? Beyond the A problem, two people in their 80s getting themselves down onto plastic sleds and riding down a snowy, bumpy hill? They must have the bodies of people half their age. This all strains credulity to the breaking point. I found the same problem with Away from Her, another movie that misrepresented the capabilities of a person with A. I know what I'm talking about because I've seen A up close too many times. There's nothing lovely about it.

SPOILER ALERT.  The climax took me by surprise, but I'm glad I hung in there. My daughter watched this and said she sobbed through it, but I didn't ask why. I watched it a week later and didn't catch on to Robert's condition until the point where the majority of viewers probably did as well. Because of her all too familiar experience with my father's behavior as she's lived with him for two years, she recognized early on in the movie the signs of dementia. The outbursts, routine, rage, confusion, and Post-It notes were clear indications to her. For me, the story unfolded with frequent awkward and odd moments. Only after the scene where his mental state is revealed did they finally make sense to me, which is the objective of a plot twist.
  I thought the director handled the story with sensitivity and gentleness and wouldn't be surprised if he had some experience himself with someone who had Alzheimer's. The acting was GREAT, and I know the actors weren't in this for the money as one reviewer wondered who gave it one star--it's an indy film, and no one does that to get rich. I gave it four stars instead of five because of the plausibility of the scenario. Most people who have someone in their lives with a condition similar to Robert Malone's will relate to this movie and be as deeply moved as we were.

Anger, fear, and helplessness in the face of mortality are more easily rationalized by the young (and especially young filmmakers?) than by the old, who may in all likelihood soon face them. This movie would benefit from an age restriction warning: something like "Contains disturbing images and depictions of hopelessness and dementia. Not suitable for persons over the age of 60."

Furthermore, several of my movie friend's stated that when watching it a second time, you catch greater subtleties within the premise of the movie and that they actually enjoyed it even more.  What could be a greater endorsement from serious movie aficionados?!

I first saw the trailer for this movie quite a while before its release.  I wrote down the title, and unfortunately forgot about it.  Flash forward a few months, and i see this movie in my recommendations on Netflix.  Well, quite frankly it still didn't ring a bell at first, but i went ahead and rented it.  Now, i'm younger than 30, male, and pretty open to movies.  But when i read the synopsis, i wasn't too thrilled about just another love story.  Ellen Burstyn was what made me take a chance.
While watching this wonderful movie, i started out pretty confused.  I questioned certain character traits in a few people, but they didn't leave a big enough impression for me to keep agonizing over them.  About 10 minutes into it, i started to smile.  The two main characters just seemed to be made for eachother, and everything they did just fit.  Scenes that would normally make my eyes roll, really touched me.  For instance, these two wonderful strangers kiss for the first time, and Christmas lights flash on.  Needless to say, my smile stayed on for quite some time.  Things just worked for these characters.

Then the pessimist in my questioned how perfect everything was.  I've seen my fair share of movies that seem good at first, then turn into train wrecks.  However, just when i was expecting the worst to happen, a glimpse of jealousy is shown from Mr. Landau's character that makes me think, "oh, here's the hitch."  Which draws my attention away from the normal "it's way too perfect to be like this the whole movie" attitude.

The different characters do very endearing acts for and with eachother, and it's all wonderful again.  And then that pesky pessimist in me is tapping my shoulder again preparing me for the worst.  Then i think i know whats going to happen, and prepare for it, and it turns out that i was yet again completely wrong.

Again, everything is back to normal, and then i have to prepare for the worst.  By the time the big reveal, the main reason this movie is so brilliant happens, i'm completely suprised, and taken aback, because this time i simply didn't prepare for it.  Everything was fine and i had this movie figured out.  Nope.  Wrong.

"Lovely, Still" sat on my Amazon Prime watchlist since I began my subscription two or three months ago.  I'd never heard of it and added it mainly because Rotten Tomatoes gave it 71% and because Martin Landau and Ellyn Burstyn are outstanding actors.  Recently watched movies I've enjoyed are, "Blackhawk Down," "Sicario," and "Bone Tomahawk," So "a romantic drama with a twist" wasn't high on my list of must-sees.  But...wow.  How could "Lovely, Still" not have been nominated for multiple Academy Awards?  Made in 2008 for $5 million, "Lovely, Still" was nominated for "Best First Screenplay" at the "Independent Spirit Awards."  Great story and Oscar-worthy performances by Landau and Burstyn.  It's one of those movies I'll watch again, probably sooner rather than later.
